facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on November 22, 1962 by RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. November, 22. The judgment of the Court was delivered by RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.-This petition under Art. 32 of the

facts.text: Petition raises question of validity of r. 16 of the Madras General Sales Tax Turnover Assessment Rules, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: Constitution raises the question of the validity of r. 16 of the Madras General Sales Tax  Turnover Assessment  Rules, 1939,

facts.text: Impugned rule r.16 published on September 7, 1955, substituted old r.16, effective from April 1, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: hereinafter called the rules. The impugned rule was published on September 7, 1955, and was substituted in the place of old r. 16.

facts.text: Petitioner is a dealer in hides and skins.

anchor.surface_text: The new rule was to be effective from April 1, 1955. The petitioner is a dealer in hides and skins.

facts.text: Petitioner sells hides and skins tanned outside the State of Madras, as well as those tanned inside the state.

anchor.surface_text: He sells hides and skins tanned outside the State of Madras, as well as those tanned inside the state. The Deputy Commercial

facts.text: Deputy Commercial Tax Officer, 1, Moore Market Division, Madras, assessed petitioner to sales tax for 1955-56 on turnover of Rs. 29,89,624-15-11.

anchor.surface_text: Tax Officer, 1, Moore Market Division, Madras, assessed the petitioner to sales tax for the year 1955-56 on a turnover of Rs.

facts.text: Out of total turnover, Rs. 28,10,625-2-0 represented sales of tanned hides and skins obtained from outside Madras.

anchor.surface_text: 29,89,624-15-11. Out of this a turnover of Rs. 28,10,625-2-0 represented sales of tanned hides and skins which had been

facts.text: Sales tax levied on hides and skins under Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 (Act IX of 1939).

anchor.surface_text: obtained from outside the State of Madras. Sales tax was levied on hides and skins under the provisions of the Madras General

facts.text: Section 3(1) of the Act: every dealer shall pay tax on total turnover at three pies per rupee.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 is the charging section and its relevant portions read 3.  1  Subject to the provisions of this Act,  a  every dealer shall pay for each year a tax on his total turnover for such year and  b  the tax shall be calculated at the rate of three pies for every rupee in such turnover - x x x x x

facts.text: Section 5(vi): sale of hides and skins liable to tax at single point in series of sales as prescribed.

anchor.surface_text: Section 5 of the Act provides for exemptions and reductions of tax in certain cases. Clause  vi   thereof provides that the sale of hides and skins, whether tanned or untanned, shall be liable to tax under section 3, sub-section  1 , only at such single point in the series of sales by successive dealers as may be prescribed.

facts.text: New rule 16(2)(i): tax on hides/skins tanned outside State levied from first dealer in State on sale price.

anchor.surface_text: 16.  1  In the case of untanned hides and or skins the tax under section 3 1  shall be levied from the dealer who is the last purchaser in the State number exempt from taxation under section 3 3  on the amount for which they are bought by him.  2   i  In the case of hides or skins which have been tanned outside the State the tax under section 3 1  shall be levied from the dealer who in the State is the first dealer in such hides or skins number exempt from taxation under section 3 3  on the amount for which they are sold by him.

facts.text: Rule 16(2)(ii): tax on hides/skins tanned within State from first dealer on sale price, but proviso exempts if tax paid on untanned under (1).

anchor.surface_text: In the case of tanned hides or skins which have been tanned within the State, the tax under section 3 1  shall be levied from a person who is the first dealer in such hides or skins number exempt from taxation under section 3 3  on the amount for which they are sold by him Provided that, if he proves that the tax has already been levied under sub-rule  1  on the untanned hides and skins out of which the tanned hides and skins had been produced, he shall number be so liable.

facts.text: Petitioner contends rule causes higher tax on tanned hides/skins imported from outside vs tanned inside State.

anchor.surface_text: It is companytended for the petitioner that the effect of this rule is that tanned hides or skins imported from outside the State and sold within the State are subject to a higher rate of tax than the tax imposed on hides or skins tanned and sold within the State-,

facts.text: Petitioner contends tax on importer's sale price vs local on raw purchase price due to proviso.

anchor.surface_text: inasmuch as sales tax on the importer hides or skins tanned outside the State is on their sale price while the tax on hides or skins tanned within the State, though ostensibly on their sale price is, in view of the proviso to cl.  ii  of sub-r.  2  of r. 16. really on the sale price of these hides or skins when they are purchased in the raw companydition

facts.text: Petitioner contends imported raw hides tanned inside subject to higher tax than local raw tanned.

anchor.surface_text: and which is substantially less than the sale price of tanned hides or skins. Further, for similar reasons, hides or skins imported from outside the State after purchase in their raw companydition and then tanned inside the State are also subject to higher taxation than hides or skins purchased in the raw companydition in the State and tanned within the State,

facts.text: Such discriminatory taxation offends Art. 304(a).

anchor.surface_text: as the tax on the former is on the sale price of the tanned hides or skins and on the latter is on the sale price of the raw hides or skins. Such a discriminatory taxation is said to offend the provisions of Art. 304 a  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Respondents contend sales tax not within Art. 304(a) as not tax on import at entry.

anchor.surface_text: The companytentions for the respondents are Sales tax does number companye within the purview of Art. 304 a  as it is number a tax on the import of goods at the point of entry.

facts.text: Respondents contend impugned rule not law by State Legislature.

anchor.surface_text: 2  The impugned rule is number a law made by the State Legislature.

facts.text: Court holds rule 16 has statutory force under s.19(5), effective as if enacted.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 16 prescribes such single point. This rule was made by the Governor in the exercise of power companyfer-red on him under s. 19 of the Act and would therefore have statutory force. In fact, sub- s.  5  of s. 19 provides that the rules shall have effect as if enacted in the Act.

facts.text: Court finds rule discriminates against imported tanned hides/skins vs local.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the privisions of r. 16  2  discriminate against the imported hides or skins which had been purchased or tanned outside the State and that therefore they companytravene the provisions of Art. 304  a  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Court holds invalid rule does not revive old r.16.

anchor.surface_text: We do number agree. Once the old rule has been substituted by the new rule, it ceases to exist and it does number automatically get revived when the new rule is held to be invalid.

facts.text: Petition maintainable, unlike Ujjam Bai case, as tax assessed under invalid rule, no jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: This petition does number companye within that decision. facts.text: Hides/skins tanned within State mostly from raw purchased in State, tax already levied on raw.

anchor.surface_text: Hides and skins tanned within the State are mostly those which had been purchased in their raw companydition in the State and therefore on which tax had already been levied on the price paid by the purchaser at the time of their sale in the raw companydition.

facts.text: Substantial disparity in price of raw hides/skins vs tanned.

anchor.surface_text: The grievance arises on account of the amount of tax levied being different on account of the existence of a substantial disparity in the price of the raw hides or skins and of those hides or skins after they had been tanned, though the rate is the same under s. 3  1   b  of the Act.

issues.text: the question of the validity of r. 16 of the Madras General Sales Tax Turnover Assessment Rules, 1939

anchor.surface_text: This petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution raises the question of the validity of r. 16 of the Madras General Sales Tax Turnover Assessment Rules, 1939, hereinafter called the rules.

issues.text: whether this rule discriminates between hides or skins imported from outside the State and those manufactured or produced in the State

anchor.surface_text: Now, the only question that remains for consideration is whether this rule discriminates between hides or skins imported from outside the State and those manufactured or produced in the State.

issues.text: whether sales tax comes within the purview of Art. 304(a)

anchor.surface_text: The contentions for the respondents are Sales tax does number come within the purview of Art. 304 a as it is number a tax on the import of goods at the point of entry.

issues.text: whether the impugned rule is a law made by the State Legislature

anchor.surface_text: 2 The impugned rule is number a law made by the State Legislature. 3 The impugned rule, by itself, does number impose the tax,

issues.text: whether the impugned rule imposes the tax or merely fixes the single point at which the tax is to be levied

anchor.surface_text: The impugned rule, by itself, does number impose the tax, but fixes the sin-ale point at which the tax imposed by ss. 3 and 5 of the Act is to be levied.

issues.text: whether the rule was made with an eye on the place of origin of the goods

anchor.surface_text: The impugned rule was number made with an eye on the place of origin of the goods but as a matter of necessity, in view of the requirements of the statutory provisions

issues.text: whether the impugned rule directly and immediately restricts or impedes the free flow of trade under Article 301

anchor.surface_text: Article 301 of the Constitution which provides for trade, commerce and intercourse throughout the territory of India to be subject to the other provisions of Part XIII, Thus considered we think it would be reasonable and proper to hold that restrictions freedom

issues.text: if the impugned rule is invalid, does the old r. 16 get revived

anchor.surface_text: It has been urged for the respondent that if the impugned rule be held to be invalid, old r. 16 gets revived and that the tax assessed on the petitioner will be good. We do number agree.

issues.text: maintainability of the petition under Article 32 in view of Ujjam Bai

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, we may refer to the Preliminary objection raised on behalf of the respondent to the maintainability of this petition, in veiw of the decision of this Court in Ujjam Bai State of Uttar Pradesh

arguments.claim: The effect of rule 16 is that tanned hides or skins imported from outside the State are subject to higher tax than those tanned within the State due to the proviso, offending Art. 304(a)

anchor.surface_text: It is contended for the petitioner that the effect of this rule is that tanned hides or skins imported from outside the State and sold within the State are subject to a higher rate of tax than the tax imposed on hides or skins tanned and sold within the State- inasmuch as sales tax on the importer hides or skins tanned outside the State is on their sale price while the tax on hides or skins tanned within the State, though ostensibly on their sale price is, in view of the proviso to cl. ii of sub-r. 2 of r. 16. really on the sale price of these hides or skins when they are purchased in the raw condition and which is substantially less than the sale price of tanned hides or skins.

Such a discriminatory taxation is said to offend the provisions of Art. 304 a of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Restrictions under Art.301 are those directly and immediately impeding free flow of trade; taxes may qualify if direct

anchor.surface_text: Article 301 of the Constitution which provides for trade, commerce and intercourse throughout the territory of India to be subject to the other provisions of Part XIII, has been construed by this Court in Atiabari Tea Co. Ltd. v. The State of Assam and Others 1 and in Automobile Transport Rajasthan Ltd. etc. v. The State of Rajasthan and Ors. 2 The majority view in the Atiabari Tea Co. Case 1 which has been accepted in the Automobile Transport Case 2 is, as expressed by Gajendragadkar, J., at p. 860 Thus considered we think it would be reasonable and proper to hold that restrictions freedom 1 1961 1. S.C.R. 809. 2 1963 1 S.C.R. 491, from which is guaranteed by Art. 301, would be such restrictions as directly and immediately restrict or impede the free flow or movement of trade.

arguments.claim: Sales tax discriminatory between states affects free flow, offends Art.301 unless complies with Art.304(a)

anchor.surface_text: Taxes may and do amount to restrictions but it is only such taxes as directly and immediately restrict trade that would fall within the purview of Art. 301... Sales tax, which has the effect of discriminating between goods of one State and goods of another, may affect the free flow of trade and it will then offend against Art. 301 and will be valid only if it comes within the terms of Art. 304 a .

arguments.claim: Art.304(a) not limited to taxes at border entry point

anchor.surface_text: The contention that Art. 304 a is attracted only when the impost is at the border, i.e., when the goods enter the State on crossing the border of the State, is not sound. Art. 304 a allows the Legislature of a State to impose taxes on goods imported from other States and does not support the contention that the imposition must be at the point of entry only.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: tates. This means that if the affect of the sales-tax on tanned hides or skins imported from outside is that the latter becomes subject to a higher ta

arguments.court_reasoning: Text allows taxes on imported goods generally, not just entry

arguments.claim: Rule 16 has statutory force as made under s.19 and effective as if enacted per s.19(5)

anchor.surface_text: Rule 16 prescribes such single point. This rule was made by the Governor in the exercise of power conferred on him under s. 19 of the Act and would therefore have statutory force. In fact, sub- s. 5 of s. 19 provides that the rules shall have effect as if enacted in the Act.

arguments.claim: Rule fixes essential step for tax imposition under ss.3/5, part of taxing enactment

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the impugned rule, by itself, does not impose the tax, but fixes the single point at which the tax imposed by ss. 3 and 5 is to be levied. What the rule provides is a step necessary for the imposition of the tax, in view of ss. 3 and 5 and therefore the impugned rule is a part of the enactment which imposes the tax.

arguments.claim: Rule 16(2) discriminates against imported tanned hides/skins vs local due to proviso and price disparity

anchor.surface_text: Now, the only question that remains for consideration is whether this rule discriminates between hides or skins imported from outside the State and those manufactured or produced in the State... We are therefore of opinion that the provisions of r. 16 2 discriminate against the imported hides or skins which had been purchased or tanned outside the State and that therefore they contravene the provisions of Art. 304 a of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Prior tax on raw local hides does not make tanned local goods different from imported tanned for Art.304(a)

anchor.surface_text: We do not consider that the mere circumstance of a tax having been paid on the sale of such hides or skins in their raw condition justifies their forming goods of a different kind from the tanned hides or skins which had been imported from outside. At the time of sale of those hides or skins in the tanned state, there was no difference between them as goods and the hides or skins tanned outside the State as goods.

arguments.claim: Invalid new rule does not revive old substituted rule

anchor.surface_text: It has been urged for the respondent that if the impugned rule be held to be invalid, old r. 16 gets revived and that the tax assessed on the petitioner will be good. We do not agree. Once the old rule has been substituted by the new rule, it ceases to exist and it does not automatically get revived when the new rule is held to be invalid.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ax having been paid on the sale of such hides or skins in their raw companydition justifies their forming goods of a different kind from the tanned hi

arguments.court_reasoning: Substituted rule ceases to exist upon substitution

arguments.claim: Petition maintainable under Art.32 as tax under invalid rule means no jurisdiction, unlike Ujjam Bai misconstrual of valid Act

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, we may refer to the Preliminary objection raised on behalf of the respondent to the maintainability of this petition, in view of the decision of this Court in Ujjam Bai State of Uttar Pradesh 3 . This petition does not come within that decision. This is not a case in which the tax has been levied by the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer by misconstruing certain provisions of a valid Act, but is a case where the taxing officer had no jurisdiction to assess the tax on account of the invalidity of the rule under which the tax was assessed.

holdings.text: The provisions of r. 16(2) discriminate against the imported hides or skins which had been purchased or tanned outside the State and therefore contravene Art. 304(a) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the privisions of r. 16 2 discriminate against the imported hides or skins which had been purchased or tanned outside the State and that therefore they companytravene the provisions of Art. 304  a  of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule taxes imported tanned hides/skins on sale price without prior raw tax credit available to local via proviso, creating higher burden despite same rate; goods similar in tanned state regardless of prior tax.

holdings.text: Sales tax which discriminates between goods of one State and another affects free flow of trade under Art. 301 and offends it unless it complies with Art. 304(a).

anchor.surface_text: Sales tax, which has the effect of discriminating between goods of one State and goods of another, may affect the free flow of trade and it will then offend against Art. 301 and will be valid only if it comes within the terms of Art. 304 a .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Atiabari and Automobile Transport, discriminatory sales tax directly impedes trade flow; not compensatory or regulatory.

holdings.text: Art. 304(a) is not limited to taxes imposed at the border or point of entry into the State.

anchor.surface_text: The contention that Art. 304 a is attracted only when the impost is at the border, i.e., when the goods enter the State on crossing the border of the State, is not sound. Art. 304 a allows the Legislature of a State to impose taxes on goods imported from other States

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading allows taxes on imported goods generally, not confined to entry point.

holdings.text: Rule 16 made under s.19 has statutory force and effect as if enacted in the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 16 prescribes such single point. This rule was made by the Governor in the exercise of power companyfer-red on him under s. 19 of the Act and would therefore have statutory force. In fact, sub- s.  5  of s. 19 provides that the rules shall have effect as if enacted in the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.19(5) expressly provides rules have effect as if enacted; Governor's rule-making power under s.19.

holdings.text: The impugned rule fixes the single point but is a necessary step and part of the tax-imposing enactment under ss.3 and 5.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the impugned rule, by itself, does number impose the tax, but fixes the single point at which the tax imposed by ss. 3 and 5 is to be levied. What the rule provides is a step necessary for the imposition of the tax, in view of ss. 3 and 5 and therefore the impugned rule is a part of the enactment which imposes the tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction: rule essential to operationalize single-point tax in s.5(vi).

holdings.text: Similarity of goods under Art. 304(a) is based on nature, quality and kind, not prior tax payment on raw materials.

anchor.surface_text: We do number companysider that the mere circumstance of a tax having been paid on the sale of such hides or skins in their raw companydition justifies their forming goods of a different kind from the tanned hides or skins which had been imported from outside. At the time of sale of those hides or skins in the tanned state, there was numberdifference between them as goods

holdings.reasoning_summary: At taxable point (tanned sale), imported and local tanned hides identical; prior raw tax irrelevant to discrimination test.

holdings.text: Invalidity of new substituting rule does not automatically revive the old substituted rule.

anchor.surface_text: We do number agree. Once the old rule has been substituted by the new rule, it ceases to exist and it does number automatically get revived when the new rule is held to be invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Substitution repeals old rule; no automatic revival upon invalidity of substitute.

holdings.text: Petition under Art.32 is maintainable as tax assessed under invalid rule deprives officer of jurisdiction, distinguishing Ujjam Bai.

anchor.surface_text: This petition does number companye within that decision. This is number a case in which the tax has been levied by the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer by misconstruing certain provisions of a valid Act, but is a case where the taxing officer had numberjuris-  1  1963 1. S.C.R. 778. diction to assess the tax on account of the invalidity of the rule under which the tax was assessed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Invalid subordinate legislation voids jurisdiction, unlike mere misconstruction of valid Act (Ujjam Bai).

precedents.citation: Atiabari Tea Co. Ltd. v. The State of Assam and Others 1

anchor.surface_text: Atiabari Tea Co. Ltd. v. The State of Assam and Others 1 and in Automobile Transport  Rajasthan  Ltd. etc. v. The State of Rajasthan and Ors.  2

precedents.case_name: Atiabari Tea Co. Ltd. v. State of Assam and Others
precedents.cited_proposition: Restrictions on freedom guaranteed by Art. 301 are such restrictions as directly and immediately restrict or impede the free flow or movement of trade; taxes that directly and immediately restrict trade fall within the purview of Art. 301
precedents.cited_holding: Thus considered we think it would be reasonable and proper to hold that restrictions freedom from which is guaranteed by Art. 301, would be such restrictions as directly and immediately restrict or impede the free flow or movement of trade. Taxes may and do amount to restrictions but it is only such taxes as directly and immediately restrict trade that would fall within the purview of Art. 301

precedents.citation: Automobile Transport  Rajasthan  Ltd. etc. v. The State of Rajasthan and Ors.  2

anchor.surface_text: Automobile Transport  Rajasthan  Ltd. etc. v. The State of Rajasthan and Ors.  2  The majority view in the Atiabari Tea Co. Case  1  which has been accepted in the Automobile Transport Case  2  is, as expressed by Gajendragadkar, J., at p. 860

precedents.case_name: Automobile Transport Rajasthan Ltd. v. State of Rajasthan and Ors.
precedents.cited_proposition: Interpretation of Art. 301 from Atiabari is correct subject to clarification that regulatory measures or compensatory taxes for use of trading facilities do not come within purview of restrictions contemplated by Art. 301; such measures do not impede but facilitate trade
precedents.cited_holding: The interpretation which was accepted by the majority in the Atiabari Tea Co. Case is correct, but subject to this clarification. Regulatory measures or measures imposing Compensatory taxes for the use of trading facilities do not come within the purview of the restrictions contemplated by Art. 301.

precedents.citation: Ujjam Bai State of Uttar Pradesh  3
